The biggest measurable difference between men and women is the male preference for things and female preference for people. More than strength, more than aggression, more than height. By asking the question in the first place, you obviously are not effeminate in that way.

Is it possible? Yes. But the weirder you are, the more you must compensate with extroversion, looks, ambition, or sacrifice attractiveness in your partner. Your better option is to be less rigid yourself, open up more socially, and frequent more common social gatherings from time to time.

This is your lucky day because this is something I struggled with for years, before seeing a really good psychologist who cured me of it. The thing that worked or me finally in our sessions was when he asked me to just pretend. Go about my day, just pretending that my appearance didn’t bother me or disturb my well-being at all. Even if I still thought I was ugly, just imagining what it would be like to not care about that. And this is all as an experiment — you can go back to letting it destroy you the next day. But guess what, the next day comes around, and you sort of liked how not caring felt. So you go on not caring. And that’s the end of it.

Assume the feeling of health, and health will be yours. Good luck

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: 13~ years here: just create circumstances where you cant watch and masturbate and start off with easypeasy even if you relapse after it. Look up what ive learned on yt, his video about willpower is for losers

posts.name: Open the link below
posts.com:
Naltrexone for addiction treatment

An addict wanting and trying to quit is a case of the rational mind deciding to stop, while the autonomous processes of the mind create cravings. Its why people have such a hard time losing weight. Rational mind chooses to lose weight and eat less, autonomous mind sends craving signals. One can understand a behavior is worth quitting and try his best to quit, yet repeatedly fail against incessant, powerful urges. Worth noting is that gambling, sex, compulsive overeating, alcoholism and drug addiction are a cluster of similar disorders. A malfunction of the brain's "reward center". See for yourself: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18241634/

Naltrexone is a helpful medication to remove the cravings. Classed as an opiate-antagonist (binds to endorphin receptors w/out "high"), Naltrexone comes in a once-monthly injection or daily pills. Absent insurance, injection is expensive and pills are inexpensive. Public health clinics, aka "community clinics" receive federal and state cost-reduction grants to serve people who lack insurance. Sliding-fee scale for most services and in the case of Naltrexone injection, often free. In the U.S. you can call 211 in most cities, a direct line to United Way. They will help you locate such a clinic. Also some anti-depressants and other psychotropic medications can help. Addicts tend to have mood or other psychiatric issues that are called "co-morbid factors". A doctor at a "community clinic" can help with that also. Naltrexone is typically taken daily for 3+ months.

Drugs.com has 500+ positive reviews about Naltrexone from actual alcoholics.

"Medical detox" refers to a doctor prescribing librium or valium for a few days to get you safely off alcohol. It works and its painless. Trying to "taper down" WITH alcohol is slow and extremely painful. Most doctors will readily offer you a medical detox prescription.

You can’t teach empathy with movies. Or even real life suffering, most of the time. People often have the misconception that psychopaths - or general assholes who get misdiagnosed by laypeople - don’t notice or understand the suffering of others. If they knew about it, surely they would care, so they must not have empathy. In reality, these people often do understand that others around them are suffering, and can picture what it would feel like. But they choose not to think about it, or to mock it and enjoy it. Or they have some other concern like their own selfish desires, which stops them from acting on empathy at any given time. These people need to be shown the personal benefits of taking an interest in others. If they are kind, they will get along with people socially, live in a smoothly run society, develop valuable long term relationships, not get in so many fights, etc. This is an extremely hard thing to teach and even harder to reinforce as a set of behaviors that last. A film is not going to cut it.

Life is stochastic, genetics affects the probability of success of a person who puts in average effort with average strategy, but assuming the correct strategy and effort, genetics should be seen merely as a hinderance to be overcome. Women are attracted to success as well as looks, so you need to be good at something and grow yourself as a person. And there are other areas in life where success is less dependent than looks than in datung. Looks can be improved significantly by exercise, good diet, and fashion. Though obviously it is partially genetically-determined, a 5/10 can become a 6/10 or 7/10 lookswise. Success in other areas can increase the overall score further even with average looks. However, simplifying to a score is both unhealthy and misleadingly simplistic. Also you say you 5/10, that is really not bad and you shouldn't focus on it. Train yourself not to care about the outcome of your life but instead to care about acting with virtue, i.e., acting in a way which makes a better life for yourself and others more likely, and let that be your focus. Genetic determinism has no affect on virtue. I have found this principle quite freeing when external factors you have no control over are involved. You should also see a therapist if you are depressed.

This is a major hurdle for Americans to understand. Yes here, anything below $60K a year is nothing anymore. I agree, but in Europe, $35K+ is good. Thing is. Hot topic here. Answer: free everything governmentally (healthcare, education, counseling, therapy, classes, amenities). I am not a liberal that thinks that all should be free, but in smaller countries like Estonia, it works.

Take Norway for example. Constantly the best country on the planet. High wages, literally free everything for citizens - BUT you pay out the ass in taxes. If you can't pay that amount, it gets carried over.

posts.sub: What's your advice for small business/ entrepreneurship?
posts.com:
Hey anons, what's some good advice you could give on managing a small business?

I want to start a small business with 2 or 3 employees which would be mainly online at first. Is there any general recommendations or stories you could share so we don't fucking die?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Here's the things you need to sort out BEFORE you try to start a business.

(1) Unironically, how to run a business. This is the number 1 downfall of small business, people jumping in without having a clue.

(2) Capital. You need enough capital to cover all business expenses while making a loss for the first 36 months of operation. Uncapitalisation is the number 2 downfall of small businesses.

(3) Record keeping. You must have a reliable, quality record keeping system particularly for tax purposes. Your system should allow you to put your hands on a requested document within 30 seconds. Anything longer than that and your system is inadequate.

(4) Write a formal business plan including financial projections.

(5) Get legal advice. Understand all of your legal obligations, applicable permit/licence requirements, regulations, etc.

(6) Understand your niche. Know your customer explicitly. "I'm just going to sell to everyone" isn't an answer. Create customer models and design your products to suit their needs/problems

(7) Design your business to fill a specific problem that is under serviced in the market. Understand this isn't about you and your goals, this is about your customer and their needs/problems.

(8) Get a good accountant.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28012815
How about instead of limiting media you maximize productivity? Spend as much time doing what you should as possible, getting all of your cleaning done, doing all the meal prep you know you should do, doing the exercise you should, then only letting media fill in the gaps. We're happiest when we have the least time available to be idle. Staying constantly busy with something will, in the long run, make you feel better. Darkness only comes when you allow yourself to contemplate it. Stay busy, don't schedule time to waste, just waste as little time as possible. You will never sleep as well as you will after a day where no time was wasted and you've worked till exhaustion. That "down time" you're seeking is meant for vacations, and even then you must be careful not to become addicted. If you're being as productive as you should, you won't need to ask this question, as it will be naturally limited by your other activities.

What we know works when it comes to behaviour change is disheartening, to say the least. I am a lawyer, but not in a common law country.

Your "philanthropist" story isn't going to amount to anything, one way or another; the judge is not going to be moved by your being a philanthropist and change their decision, even if they believed it.

If you lie about something irrelevant for the case, like being a philanthropist, it might reflect poorly on you, but is unlikely to have any drastic consequences.

The rest of what you say, however, might have drastic consequences, and you should consult with a lawyer in your jurisdiction before doing irreparable harm to yourself.

Led to a string of casual relationships that gave me a lot more confidence, experience, and competence navigating dating. It's funny, but dating is largely just grinding. Sucks at first, can get repetitive, eventually you learn the tricks and it pays off. Just don't let your mistakes deter you from pushing forward. posts.sub: How can I be more superficial and fun?
posts.com:
I've been consumed by reading, thinking, and trying to find answers to politics, philosophy, religion, the meaning of life, etc., for the past few years. Now I'm done because I realized that I'm never going to find clean cut answers to those questions, so I found an answer that works for me and cut my losses. Unfortunately, I put almost all my other hobbies and interests on hold, and now I've become way too boring, serious, and unimaginative of a person (when I was already pretty serious to begin).

So, how can I be more superficial, light-hearted and fun? It seems like even something as simple as making jokes, looking forward to the next movie, playing a character, etc., has a lot of depth to it, even if it's all appearances. I know that practice makes perfect, but it's one of those things that I have no idea where to begin working on because it's so alien to me now. It's like I almost got rid of my entire personality for this quest.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28006809
Just enjoy fun stuff. That's it.
Preferably watch comedy stuff like Monty Python or The Office, as getting into other serious stuff like The Sopranos will still make you a boring guy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28006809
Don't refer to these people as superficial please.
You're not even that deep, everyone goes through the same shit, but manifests it in completely different ways.
It's just a phase of growing up, you'll need to adapt later in life, since I assume that you're pretty young. You don't need to fake anything, just get some friends and hang out with them, and learn that life isn't too serious.
Try to learn what's enjoyable and what's not, and how to enjoy it yourself, but there's no need to call the mundane things superficial, or feel superior to people who enjoy them. Just be open minded.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28015068
Don't worry, I've been exploring the faith for a while now (redoubled my efforts lately), and I appreciate the extra nudge. I've been reading the Bible, thinking about it and trying to apply it to my life, and looking for thoughtful Biblical commentary wherever I could find it.

The funny thing is that even religion can lead astray. I realized that a big portion of my search for God was completely misguided (and thus my faith stunted) because I thought religion had to do with being a good person. Then it became a quest of finding the perfect philosophy, the perfect mysticism, the perfect politics, etc., to repair an utterly broken society. It was such a prideful, silly, and vain venture, even if society forces you to care about the impossible. No, you don't have to be religious to be a good person, at least in the eyes of society. You can always be "good enough" and carve out your rewards later. Society is about getting our needs met, the bare minimums, and rarely does it rise above that standard (because we simply don't *have* to).

The whole point of Christ's revelation is that everything, EVERYTHING worldly falls short of God, that Christ died for our sins, and Christ's sacrifice enables us to embrace the gift of eternal life. In that moment, He opened the way for us to follow in His footsteps, to surrender to the radical freedom (and the subsequent radical responsibility) of living life in communion with God, to excel beyond what the moral standards of the day call for and to embody God's love on Earth with what little time I have in this world. I realized that I could never be the perfect person I wanted to be in the eyes of God, yet nothing else short of that flame would ever satisfy me either. I've been hungering for that realization so I could imbibe it until it consumed every fiber of my being.

That's the reason why I "cut my losses" in the OP btw lol. It left me much happier, understanding my place in the universe and accepting it.

You need to educate yourself about improving your mental health.
Over the years I learnt EMDR do handle trauma and intrusive thoughts, I learnt how to meditate, I researched what medications could tackle my symptoms and discarded those who weren't working. I went to therapy and did some progress. I'm doing exercise HIIT workouts several times a week, etc. I got better sleep circadian rhythms, etc. Basically it's lisfestyle stuff to lower inflammation, and keep BDNF high, metabolism high, stress low, etc.

But overall I realistically accepted my limitations, and that I'll be always someone who lacks in the emotional and social, despite being high I.Q. etc. I have a decades long term relationship with someone who tolerates my shut-ins and schizoid behaviour, and we became parents, our kid is normal and better adjusted than us, (for a zoomer).

So it's doable, but you don't have to force yourself to be a normie, that's a huge error.

If you feel suicidal, research about ketamine clinics, a professional could help you with that, Ketamine and esketamine is the future of psychiatric interventions, in contrast with SSRIs you still have suicidal thoughts, or even paradoxically more, but with ketamine and other psychoplastogens (i.e. DXM, psilocibin, etc) after the first intake you'll feel way better and without suicidal thoughts.

posts.name: Planning
posts.com:
>>28014194
One of the key things I would advise and try my best to stick to is to try and do the prep for your tutorials at the start of the week. Whilst this idea may not exactly apply to your subject (I do languages) - If you get this out of the way by Monday / Tuesday for the weeks classes - even better if on the weekend before - you can plan out and dedicate time in particular to your assignments

posts.name: Planning
posts.com:
>>28014194

From then on if you seem to struggle with messing up your timetable and then letting it crumble you have to accept a couple of things which once you do will better allow you to stick to your schedule

- firstly - particularly if you are at university - you have to accept that you may have to do late nights to make up lost time or do extra work on tight deadlines if you didn’t stick to your schedule earlier in the week - Secondly - and most important but often the hardest !!!! - GET UP IN THE MORNINGS. I am v temperamental with this but I have made a marked improvement This academic year in getting up and not wasting the mornings - even if you don’t do any or much work in the mornings - it means you can get the moping / showering / phone use all out of the way and have a productive afternoon - CRUCIALLY - accept that some days you won’t get much sleep. Don’t stay in bed unless you are exhausted and running on multiple nights of missed sleep. Good luck anon I hope this finds you well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For as long as i can remember i always hated when people complimented me, for some reason it always felt worse than an insult.
I specially dreaded when people called me smart, in the beginning i thought it was because i think that the mere concept of "smart" is subjective as shit, and people just like to throw it around randomly. But nowadays i think it's because i always felt alienated whenever someone decided to label me as "smart".
It meant that i wasn't normal, it meant that i wasn't part of the group, it meant that i wasn't really an equal to my peers or even to my own family.
I was always "the smart one", the one people asked for advice, the one that always had an answer or a plan, the one that was always right and thus it was pointless to even question what i said.
Nobody tried to understand me, they just accepted me and everything i said as a fact because they thought "i'm probably to dumb to understand it anyways".
Every time i tried to bring this up to someone, it ended up sounding like humble bragging to them, so i just stopped.
But then i met her, someone hardworking, curious, disciplined and "smart", and when SHE called me smart, for the first time in my life i didn't felt alienated, because i knew she didn't say it as a way to put a barrier between us, but as a way of saying "you are like me".
I've only known her for around 2.5 months, but the time i've spent with her has been the happiest i've been in a very long time.
At this point, i'm not even sure what i feel for her, but i sure as shit know that i feel something.

M, i know you will never read this, but i hope you could see yourself through my eyes, you are a wonderful person, it's just that you just haven't realised it yet.

>>28012996
I am straight. I get warm feelings when I think about the girl I know I'm crushing on, I want to be with her and have a family, and I enjoy how she thinks and talks and acts, and yet my OCD harasses me about sexuality.
I am not trans. I take pride in my body, and I've never fantasized about transitioning nor does it appeal to me. I don't feel dysphoria. Yet my OCD harasses me into wondering *what if* I had dysphoria.
OCD is a special hell and I am getting therapy because meds are not available to me, but no one without OCD ever understands. I do not align with my intrusive thoughts, but people, as soon as it comes up, assume I must secretly desire to act on my intrusive thoughts. They ruined my life (couldn't drive because of them for a while, couldn't leave the house for a few months in my teens, etc) and yet it's treated as a quirky thing. I hate how this suicide inducing condition is rendered impotent as a label because it's "cute" and "trendy" and "aesthetic." Oh well. I'm pursuing this girl and I have high hopes but I wonder if I should just call it off because of the thoughts. Yet I know they won't go away. So I must act as if they will not. So I ask myself: am I content dying alone? Hell no. As a result, I struggle against it, knowing this condition eats me. If only my psychologist let me drink or cope in some unhealthy vice rather than face the horrid thoughts constantly. I /have/ improved, but the agony is overwhelming tonight, the most since 2021.

>>28014619
Well you have to start here. There's got to be something that you're interested in that you can also translate into a marketable skill that will earn you a good living.

You could also take the other anon's advice and work with what you've got. If there's nothing else you're interested in, you need to at least find out how to maneuver your way around to a management position at your current job, and then level up from there.
At least you have a bachelor's degree. You could take some continuing education course in "management" (idk what the specific term would be) part time at a university, then lobby for a promotion or start applying for "department manager" type roles at other companies similar to where you work now.
If you do the continuing education thing, make sure it's at a well known institution and that their courses (and certificates) are officially recognized by whatever industry you're involved in right now.

Just don't wallow in despair. There are ways to turn your life around, if you really want to. But you have to be willing to figure it out yourself. I believe in you anon :)

>>28013233
>Drinking on the job
Was a totally normal and expected thing for hundreds and hundreds of years.

Only recently has it been looked down upon. Offices used to have booze in the lounges, and most bosses had a mini-bar in their office.

A "liquid lunch" of 2-5 drinks and cigs or cigars was the norm in the business world.

Drinks at the end of the day also normal, but after biz hours.

Only jobs that didn't drink on the job were certain industrial ones that required more concentration to avoid accidents, but even thenyou usually didn't get fired for drinking, as long as you were still able to do the job safely.

The world is fucked up now. Trannies grooming kids in schools, but nobody allowed a beer at lunch anymore.

>>28013345
I agree with this sentiment, OP. Take it straight from me, man. I went into nursing school in the early 2010s because I liked science, and it was an in-demand field. I went into nursing school and made it one year in and left. I couldn't handle the patient interactions, I despised patients who refused to heed my advice, and the medical system in America is a fucking joke. What I did like was computers and IT, business stuff. I remember sending the email off and them calling me in and I told them, and I felt a weight lifted off me. My dad supported me, my mom was furious. I'm glad I left. Medical professionals are treated like dirt by the public and the medical system's administrators.

Anyway, you're going about this wrong, OP. I do IT management, hire plenty of young people. Most of them don't have a fucking clue what they want to do. The good ones I know have their shit together, they have a plan that is 5, 10 years down the line.

Go here https://www.bls.gov/ooh/

This is the Bureau of Labor Statistics Occupational Outlook Handbook. It's basically a 24/7 self-service career counselor on crack. It tells you about jobs that apply to what degrees, any requirements, and their trendiness (aka is this job getting more popular or is it about to be obsolete for some reason. Is pay going up, down, or flatlined?). Now, find 10, yes 10, not 5, jobs you would like to do that are math oriented. Write them down in an excel spreadsheet or a notepad, make notes of the degrees, salary, education and licensure requirements. Now go find a mid-tier state school and get your degree (top tier IVY league shit is a fucking meme unless you need it for networking. You don't. You need a proper math/STEM program). You may find something interesting, like encryption shit, financial shit, etc. Be flexible, but know that if you are a math geek, some Thomas Edison will pay you a lot to crunch numbers to help innovate some shit. And you don't have to do residency.
